plus: The user-removable SSD makes for easy upgrades and data security that doesn't require device destruction.
To the extent that screws are used, they are all standard Torx fasteners.
minus: The battery is firmly glued in place, with its connector pinned under the motherboard—requiring near-total disassembly for service.
As with all iPads, a solid barrier of very strong adhesive hinders all repairs.
The Lightning port, a common point of failure, is soldered to the logic board.
More adhesive holds nearly everything else in place. Battery and logic board replacements are particularly obnoxious.

plus: All screws are standard Torx or Phillips—only three drivers are needed for complete disassembly.
Easy access to repair documentation and replacement parts by HP makes self-repair more feasible.
A modular and flat construction allows access to most components early on.
All screws are standard T5 Torx, Phillips #1, or Phillips #0.
Manufacturer providedrepair documentationtakes the guesswork out of repair.
Removing the battery, display, and system board is relatively straightforward and does not require fighting against adhesive

minus: Battery replacement is possible, but still unnecessarily difficult.

plus: All screws are standard Torx or Phillips.

minus: Gobs of adhesive hold most everything in place, making all repairs more difficult.

plus: LCD and front glass are not fused and can be replaced individually.

minus: High wear components soldered in place, which increases replacement costs.

plus: The battery was very easy to remove.

minus: Thin layer of adhesive that needed to broken in order to remove the bezel and access the internal components.

plus: The display is easily removed from the simple clips holding it to the body, simplifying repairs.

minus: The battery is extremely difficult to remove, even with heat and prying.

plus: The plastic case assembly is held together by clips and no adhesive, and opening only requires prying with an iFixit opening tool.
The digitizer and LCD panel are not fused together.
minus: Removing the digitizer and LCD panel requires fighting through some very resilient adhesive.

plus: Display is easy to remove and has no adhesive.
Most commonly-failing components, including all the ports and buttons and  are modular and can be replaced quickly.
minus: RAM and SSD are soldered to the motherboard and non-upgradable.

plus: Rear case is secured by clips, not glue, and is flexible enough to remove fairly easily.
Non-proprietary Phillips screws used throughout.
minus: Battery is held in place with excessive adhesive. A hole in the midframe means prying the battery out may risk damaging the back of the display.

plus: Many parts are modular and can be replaced independently.
minus: The delicate and arduous opening procedure leaves no room for mistakes, and must be completed to access any other component.
The display assembly consists of a thin fused glass panel and LCD, and is extremely difficult to remove and replace.

plus: Many components (including the headphone jack, speakers, and micro SD slot) are modular and can be replaced.
minus: In order to repair or replace anything, both the front and rear panel need to be removed.
The front and rear panel are secured in place with a lot of adhesive, and are extremely hard to remove.
Adhesive holds many components in place, including the display and battery.
Replacement of any part requires removal of the display assembly, an easy part to damage.
The SSD is no longer replaceable.
The fused front panel increases the cost of screen repair, and the risk of damaging the LCD when opening.
Gobs of adhesive hold everything in place, making all repairs more difficult.

plus: Very modular design allows independent replacement of several wear-prone components—like the headphone jack and speakers.
Only very mild adhesive holds the battery in place, making it fairly easy to safely remove and replace.
minus: Display assembly is a single fused component, that requires disassembling the entire phone to replace.
Just like in previous iPads, the front panel is glued to the rest of the device, greatly increasing the chances of cracking the glass during a repair.

The LCD has foam sticky tape adhering it to the front panel, increasing chances of it being shattered during disassembly.
